title: Boy, 9, cries in court after being accused of murdering 5 family members in fire
text:

A nine-year-old boy left a court in tears after being accused of murdering five of his relatives in one night.

Kyle Alwood stands accused of deliberately starting the blaze that killed five members of his family in Chicago, Illinois, in April.

The youngster was barely visible when he appeared in an Illinois court yesterday as his head could only just be seen above the back of his chair.

Alwood's mum, Katie Alwood, previously denied her son was a monster and described the fire as a mistake.

(Image: Facebook)

(Image: Legacy.com)

Alwood's lawyer had to explain some of the judge's words to him in court, including 'alleged', 'arson' and 'residence', CBS News reports.

The teary child was accompanied by his grandfather as he left the courtroom.

According to CBS News, his mum previously said: "People make mistakes and that's what this is. Yes, it was a horrible tragedy, but it's still not something to throw his life away over."

Ms Alwood's children, Daemeon and Ariel Wall, aged two and one, her grandmother, her fiancé and her niece, two, died in the mobile home fire.

She described the heartbreaking moment she had to say goodbye to her children as the blaze raged.

(Image: Legacy.com)

(Image: Legacy.com)

The mum, who is still in a Chicago hospital, said: "I stood at the window and I told my kids I was sorry I couldn't save them.

"Mommy was right here and I loved them. You know, so, at least hopefully they heard that. I told Jason I loved him... And then something told me that they're gone."

She added that her son had been diagnosed with schizophrenia, ADHD and bipolar disorder.

The controversial decision to charge such a young boy with murder has sent ripples through the American legal community.

(Image: 25 News)

(Image: 25 News)

One lawyer has argued children young enough to believe in Santa Claus can't form intent to commit murder, according to reports.

Woodford County State’s Attorney Greg Minger told US media "it was a heavy decision" to charge the boy.

He said: "It’s a tragedy, but at the end of the day it’s charging a very young person with one of the most serious crimes we have."
description: The lawyer for Kyle Alwood, nine, had to explain certain words to him in court, including 'alleged', 'arson' and 'residence', it is claimed
